name: Neutrogena Skin360

highlights: This was the first project I worked on as a brand new software developer, and I got to help see it through many iterations over the years, including a mobile app. I was also given audit reports from the Kenvue team in Canada (where there are stricter web accessibility standards) whenever small remediations were needed.

name: Concern Worldwide USA - Beyond Barriers

highlights: It's a great feeling when a client you've worked with in the past wants to work with you again! I used Google Charts for the first time on this project to create data visualizations for the client's research survey results. It was very challenging, but I can learn to do anything, and the result was that much more rewarding.

name: Kinetic Demolition
highlights: This was the first project I took the lead on. Once the design was finalized, the reigns were handed over to me for creating the development plan. I lead development, acting as project manager for the dev team and doing code reviews. Being a relatively small site, this was the perfect first go at being lead developer.
imageAlt: The landing page of the Kinetic Demolition website.

name: Grafton Studio
stack: Astro, React components, Storybook for component development and testing, Sanity CMS
highlights: Right after I joined Grafton Studio in 2020, we launched a new “temporary” single-page site. Three years later, we finally had time to build ourselves a proper site! After proving myself on the Kinetic Demolition project, I was tapped again as lead developer. I took it as a huge vote of confidence that the whole team entrusted me with that responsibility for our company's own website. This was also my first time exploring Sanity CMS, and I loved it so much!
imageAlt: The landing page of the Grafton Studio website.

name: MyGiide
highlights: This was the second project of my professional developer career, and I got to revisit it last year for accessibility remediations. The client had a very exciting opportunity to partner with a public university where this app would be used in classrooms. I was given an accessibility audit report done by a third party, did all the necessary remediation to get the app compliant with Section 508, and drafted a Voluntary Product Accessibility Template for the client. My remediation work was essential to their ability to sign a lucrative deal with the university. It was so fulfilling to do this work knowing it would improve the experience of using the app for all of the students. It was also very cool to see how much I had learned about web accessibility in the 3 years since the app was first launched!
imageAlt: The compare yourself to others page of the MyGiide web app.

name: ACIR
highlights: This site was first launched over 10 years ago and is in need of an accessibility overhaul. I was able to go through the whole site and create an audit report with remediation recommendations to get it into compliance with WCAG Level AA.
imageAlt: The landing page of the ACIR website.

imageAlt: The landing page of the MIT age lab site.

name: MIT AgeLab - Mapping the Caregiver Journey
highlights: This project involved recreating an old archived site with important research for the Agelab. The original version of the site was composed largely of images and graphics as data visualizations, with no accessible alternative. Navigating the site with a screen reader felt like surfing mostly empty pages. I created markdown fields in the client's existing CMS so that I could organize all of the text and data from the image graphics into tables. This enabled me to render the data as visually-hidden HTML elements on the front end, vastly improving the site for any visually-impaired or non-sighted users.
imageAlt: The landing page of the MIT age lab site.
